1. Bug spray Use a bug spray that uses 20 to 30% DEET

 2. Cover up Wear more clothes to reduce chances of bites and stings

 3. For painful bites/stings Take an over-the-counter painkiller like advil or ibuprofen

 4. For itchy bites Apply an anti-itch cream or topical ointment like hydrocortisone

 5. To reduce swelling Use ice or ice patches to reduce swelling.
Use the slider and toggle button to create custom sounds to be played! Sounds are in units of kHz.

We do NOT recommend using this app if you own rodents like rats, mice, guinea pigs, hamsters, and gerbils. This app emits sounds above 80,000 Hz. Small rodents can hear sounds up to 90,000 Hz, cats up to 60,000 Hz, and dogs up to 40,000 Hz. (For reference, humans hear up to 20,000 Hz.) If you live in a small apartment or duplex, we recommend checking in with your neighbors before using this app.

Are the sounds emitted by this app harmful to household pets?

Ultrasonic pest repellers emit high-frequency sound waves inaudible to humans. These sounds are extremely irritating to cockroaches, mice, wasps, and other disagreeable pests. While these sounds do not kill anything, they are highly aggravating, deterring pests from nesting or staying near the sound’s source (your phone).
Is this app a viable replacement to pest control?

There are downsides to extreme measures of pest control. The cost can run high. Poison can be harmful to children, pregnant and nursing women, and pets. That being said, if you are facing an infestation that is degrading your quality of life, you should contact your local pest control.
Is ultrasonic pest repellent technology backed by science?
As of now, no. The studies on it are far and few.
